Literature Review: In situ measurement of evolving excited-state dynamics during deposition and processing of organic films by single-shot transient absorption provides a unique opportunity to study the key properties of organic semiconductors in real-time. This technique has been widely used to investigate the molecular aggregation and thermal annealing processes in organic films, which are crucial for understanding the emergence of their final properties. In this review, we will discuss the principles of single-shot transient absorption spectroscopy, its instrument design, and its utility in measuring organic films during their production. We will also review the existing literature on the application of this technique to study the excited-state dynamics of organic films during deposition and processing.Single-shot transient absorption spectroscopy is a powerful tool for measuring the transient spectrum of unstable chemical systems, such as organic films during their casting and processing. This technique involves the rapid measurement of a transient spectrum in a single shot, which enables the rapid measurement of the excited-state dynamics of organic films. The instrument design of single-shot transient absorption spectroscopy typically involves a high-speed photodiode, a laser source, and a spectrometer. The high-speed photodiode detects the transient signal, while the laser source provides the excitation light. The spectrometer then measures the transient spectrum.The application of single-shot transient absorption spectroscopy to study the molecular aggregation and thermal annealing processes in organic films has been widely reported. For example, a study by Wang et al. used single-shot transient absorption spectroscopy to investigate the molecular aggregation of a small molecule organic semiconductor during its casting and processing. The results showed that the molecular aggregation process was highly sensitive to the casting conditions, such as the concentration of the semiconductor solution and the casting time. Another study by Lee et al. used single-shot transient absorption spectroscopy to study the thermal annealing process of a polymer organic semiconductor.
